**Margaret Ruth Kidder** (October 17, 1948 – May 13, 2018), professionally
known as **Margot Kidder** , was a Canadian-American actress and
[activist](/wiki/Activism "Activism"). She rose to fame in 1978 for her role
as [Lois Lane](/wiki/Lois_Lane "Lois Lane") in the [_Superman_ film
series](/wiki/Superman_in_film#Christopher_Reeve_series_.281978.E2.80.931987.29
"Superman in film"), alongside [Christopher Reeve](/wiki/Christopher_Reeve
"Christopher Reeve").

Kidder began her career in the 1960s appearing in low-budget Canadian films
and television series, before landing a lead role in _[Quackser Fortune Has a
Cousin in the Bronx](/wiki/Quackser_Fortune_Has_a_Cousin_in_the_Bronx
"Quackser Fortune Has a Cousin in the Bronx")_ (1970). She then played
[twins](/wiki/Twin "Twin") in [Brian De Palma](/wiki/Brian_De_Palma "Brian De
Palma")'s cult thriller _[Sisters](/wiki/Sisters_\(1973_film\) "Sisters \(1973
film\)")_ (1973), a sorority student in the slasher film _[Black
Christmas](/wiki/Black_Christmas_\(1974_film\) "Black Christmas \(1974
film\)")_ (1974) and the titular character's girlfriend in the drama _[The
Great Waldo Pepper](/wiki/The_Great_Waldo_Pepper "The Great Waldo Pepper")_
(1975), opposite [Robert Redford](/wiki/Robert_Redford "Robert Redford"). Her
performance as [Kathy Lutz](/wiki/Kathy_Lutz "Kathy Lutz") in the blockbuster
horror film _[The Amityville Horror](/wiki/The_Amityville_Horror_\(1979_film\)
"The Amityville Horror \(1979 film\)")_ (1979) gained her further mainstream
exposure.

By the late 1980s, Kidder's career began to slow. In 1996, she had a highly
publicized [manic](/wiki/Mania "Mania") episode and [nervous
breakdown](/wiki/Nervous_breakdown "Nervous breakdown"). By the 2000s, she
maintained steady work in independent films and television, with guest-
starring roles on _[Smallville](/wiki/Smallville "Smallville")_ , _[Brothers&
Sisters](/wiki/Brothers_and_Sisters_\(2006_TV_series\) "Brothers and Sisters
\(2006 TV series\)")_ and _[The L Word](/wiki/The_L_Word "The L Word")_. In
2015, she won a [Daytime Emmy
Award](/wiki/Daytime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Performer_in_Children%27s_Programming
"Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Performer in Children's Programming") for
her performance on the children's television series _[R.L. Stine's The
Haunting Hour](/wiki/R.L._Stine%27s_The_Haunting_Hour "R.L. Stine's The
Haunting Hour")_. She also acted in theatrical productions, most notably
appearing on [Broadway](/wiki/Broadway_theatre "Broadway theatre") in a 2002
production of _[The Vagina Monologues](/wiki/The_Vagina_Monologues "The Vagina
Monologues")_.

In 2005, Kidder became a naturalized U.S. citizen. She was an outspoken
[political](/wiki/Political_activism "Political activism"),
[environmental](/wiki/Environmental_activism "Environmental activism") and
[anti-war](/wiki/Anti-war_movement "Anti-war movement") activist.[1]

## Early life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Margot_Kidder&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Early life")]

Kidder, one of five children, was born in [Yellowknife](/wiki/Yellowknife
"Yellowknife"), [Northwest Territories](/wiki/Northwest_Territories "Northwest
Territories"), the daughter of Jocelyn Mary "Jill"
([née](/wiki/Married_and_maiden_names "Married and maiden names") Wilson), a
history teacher, and Kendall Kidder, an explosives expert and
engineer.[2][3][4] Kidder also spent time growing up in [Labrador
City](/wiki/Labrador_City "Labrador City"), [Newfoundland and
Labrador](/wiki/Newfoundland_and_Labrador "Newfoundland and Labrador").[5] Her
mother was from [British Columbia](/wiki/British_Columbia "British Columbia"),
Canada, and her father was from [New Mexico](/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico"),
[United States](/wiki/United_States_of_America "United States of America").[6]
She was of [Welsh](/wiki/Welsh_people "Welsh people") and
[English](/wiki/English_people "English people") descent.[7]

Kidder was born in Yellowknife because of her father's job, which required the
family to live in remote locations.[8] Her father was manager of the
Yellowknife Telephone Company from 1948-51. Kidder recalled her childhood in
northern Canada, saying, "We didn't have movies in this little mining town.
When I was 12 my mom took me to [New York](/wiki/New_York_City "New York
City") and I saw _[Bye Bye Birdie](/wiki/Bye_Bye_Birdie "Bye Bye Birdie")_ ,
with people singing and dancing, and that was it. I knew I had to go far away.
I was clueless, but I [have done] okay."[9]

Kidder attended multiple schools in her youth, and graduated from [Havergal
College](/wiki/Havergal_College "Havergal College"), a boarding school in
[Toronto](/wiki/Toronto,_Ontario "Toronto, Ontario"), in 1966.[10] She had a
sister, Annie[nb 1], who is a Canadian actress and executive director of the
_People for Education_ charity, and three brothers: John, Michael and Peter.
Kidder's niece [Janet Kidder](/wiki/Janet_Kidder "Janet Kidder") is also an
actress.[11]

### 1968–1974: Early
work[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Margot_Kidder&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: 1968–1974: Early work")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Margot_Kidder_Gaily%2C_Gaily.png/170px-
Margot_Kidder_Gaily%2C_Gaily.png)](/wiki/File:Margot_Kidder_Gaily,_Gaily.png)

[](/wiki/File:Margot_Kidder_Gaily,_Gaily.png "Enlarge")

Margot Kidder in _[Gaily, Gaily](/wiki/Gaily,_Gaily "Gaily, Gaily")_ (1969)

Kidder made her film debut in a 49-minute film titled _[The Best Damn Fiddler
from Calabogie to
Kaladar](/wiki/The_Best_Damn_Fiddler_from_Calabogie_to_Kaladar "The Best Damn
Fiddler from Calabogie to Kaladar")_ (1968), a drama set in a Canadian logging
community, which was produced by the [Challenge for
Change](/wiki/Challenge_for_Change "Challenge for Change").[12] Her first
major feature was the 1969 American film _[Gaily, Gaily](/wiki/Gaily,_Gaily
"Gaily, Gaily")_ , a comedy starring [Beau Bridges](/wiki/Beau_Bridges "Beau
Bridges"). She appeared in a number of TV drama series for the
[CBC](/wiki/CBC_Television "CBC Television"), including guest appearances on
_[Wojeck](/wiki/Wojeck "Wojeck")_ , _[Adventures in Rainbow
Country](/wiki/Adventures_in_Rainbow_Country "Adventures in Rainbow Country")_
, and a semi-regular role as a young reporter on
_[McQueen](/wiki/McQueen_\(TV_series\) "McQueen \(TV series\)")_ , and as a
panelist on _Mantrap_ which featured discussions centered on a feminist
perspective.[13] During the 1971–72 season, she co-starred as barmaid Ruth in
_[Nichols](/wiki/Nichols_\(TV_series\) "Nichols \(TV series\)")_ , a [James
Garner](/wiki/James_Garner "James Garner") western, which aired 22 episodes on
[NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC").

In the late 1960s, Kidder was based in Toronto, and in 1970, relocated to
[Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver "Vancouver").[14] During an August 3, 1970
interview on _[The Dick Cavett Show](/wiki/The_Dick_Cavett_Show "The Dick
Cavett Show")_ , Kidder stated that she was ambivalent toward having a film
career, and was considering working as a [film editor](/wiki/Film_editor "Film
editor") in the future.[14] She appeared in "Such Dust As Dreams Are Made On",
the first pilot for _[Harry O](/wiki/Harry_O "Harry O")_ which aired in March
1973. She was a [guest star](/wiki/Guest_star "Guest star") in a 1972 episode
of the [George Peppard](/wiki/George_Peppard "George Peppard") detective
series _[Banacek](/wiki/Banacek "Banacek")_.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Gene_Wilder_Margot_Kidder_1970.png/170px-
Gene_Wilder_Margot_Kidder_1970.png)](/wiki/File:Gene_Wilder_Margot_Kidder_1970.png)

[](/wiki/File:Gene_Wilder_Margot_Kidder_1970.png "Enlarge")

Kidder with [Gene Wilder](/wiki/Gene_Wilder "Gene Wilder") in _[Quackser
Fortune Has a Cousin in the
Bronx](/wiki/Quackser_Fortune_Has_a_Cousin_in_the_Bronx "Quackser Fortune Has
a Cousin in the Bronx")_ (1970)

After moving to Los Angeles, Kidder was cast opposite [Gene
Wilder](/wiki/Gene_Wilder "Gene Wilder") in _[Quackser Fortune Has a Cousin in
the Bronx](/wiki/Quackser_Fortune_Has_a_Cousin_in_the_Bronx "Quackser Fortune
Has a Cousin in the Bronx")_ (1970) as an exchange student in Ireland who
becomes the love interest of a poor horse manure collector in Dublin whom she
almost runs over with her car. After filming in Ireland, Kidder relocated to
[New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") to further study
acting.[15] A year later, she returned to California, and was cast in the
[Brian De Palma](/wiki/Brian_De_Palma "Brian De Palma") cult classic
_[Sisters](/wiki/Sisters_\(1973_film\) "Sisters \(1973 film\)")_ (1973), which
gained notoriety for both director and Kidder, who as leading lady, portrayed
[conjoined twins](/wiki/Conjoined_twins "Conjoined twins").[9] Kidder had been
in a relationship with De Palma at the time, and had been roommates with co-
star [Jennifer Salt](/wiki/Jennifer_Salt "Jennifer Salt") in Los Angeles.[16]
She then starred in the slasher film _[Black
Christmas](/wiki/Black_Christmas_\(1974_film\) "Black Christmas \(1974
film\)")_ in 1974, for which she won a [Canadian Film
Award](/wiki/Canadian_Film_Award "Canadian Film Award") for Best Actress;
followed by a role as a prostitute in the [Terrence
Malick](/wiki/Terrence_Malick "Terrence Malick")-scripted _[The Gravy
Train](/wiki/The_Gravy_Train "The Gravy Train")_ (1974).[16] She received
another Canadian Film Award for Best Actress for her performance in the war
drama _[A Quiet Day in Belfast](/wiki/A_Quiet_Day_in_Belfast "A Quiet Day in
Belfast")_ (1974).[17]

### 1975–1979: _Superman_ , mainstream
recognition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Margot_Kidder&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: 1975–1979: Superman, mainstream recognition")]

In 1975, Kidder was cast in a lead role in _[The Great Waldo
Pepper](/wiki/The_Great_Waldo_Pepper "The Great Waldo Pepper")_ opposite
[Robert Redford](/wiki/Robert_Redford "Robert Redford"), she also appeared in
_[The Reincarnation of Peter Proud](/wiki/The_Reincarnation_of_Peter_Proud
"The Reincarnation of Peter Proud")_ and _[92 in the
Shade](/wiki/92_in_the_Shade_\(film\) "92 in the Shade \(film\)")_ (1975) with
[Peter Fonda](/wiki/Peter_Fonda "Peter Fonda"), all of which established her
as a commercially viable leading lady.[17] Kidder famously married the
director of _92 in the Shade_ , [Thomas McGuane](/wiki/Thomas_McGuane "Thomas
McGuane"). She appeared in the March 9, 1975 edition of _[The American
Sportsman](/wiki/The_American_Sportsman "The American Sportsman")_ , learning
how to [hang glide](/wiki/Hang_gliding "Hang gliding"), and providing the
narration, with a remote microphone recording her reactions in flight; the
segment concluded with Kidder doing solos soaring amid the Wyoming
Rockies.[18]

Kidder appeared in the March 1975 issue of _Playboy_ , photographed in black
and white by Douglas Kirkland, with the article written by Kidder herself.[19]

After taking a break from acting after the birth of her daughter in 1976,
Kidder sought to return to making films in the late 1970s. After doing a
reading of [Lois Lane](/wiki/Lois_Lane "Lois Lane") for the 1978 superhero
film _[Superman: The Movie](/wiki/Superman_\(1978_film\) "Superman \(1978
film\)")_ , Kidder was flown to England by [Richard
Donner](/wiki/Richard_Donner "Richard Donner") for screen-tests.[16] Donner
ultimately cast Kidder in the role, which would become her most iconic.[16]
Filming took over a year, and the film was released during Christmas 1978, to
major commercial success. Kidder won a [Saturn Award](/wiki/Saturn_Award
"Saturn Award") for [best actress](/wiki/Saturn_Award_for_Best_Actress "Saturn
Award for Best Actress") for her performance in the film. Kidder publicly
disagreed with the decision of producers [Alexander
Salkind](/wiki/Alexander_Salkind "Alexander Salkind") and [Ilya
Salkind](/wiki/Ilya_Salkind "Ilya Salkind") to replace [Richard
Donner](/wiki/Richard_Donner "Richard Donner") as director for _[Superman
II](/wiki/Superman_II "Superman II")_ (1980).[20] It was reported that as a
result, Kidder's role in _[Superman III](/wiki/Superman_III "Superman III")_
(1983) consisted of less than five minutes of footage,[21] though the
producers have denied this in DVD commentaries. Her role in _[Superman IV: The
Quest for Peace](/wiki/Superman_IV:_The_Quest_for_Peace "Superman IV: The
Quest for Peace")_ (1987) was more substantial.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Kidder's performance as [Kathy Lutz](/wiki/Kathy_Lutz "Kathy Lutz") in the
1979 summer release of _[The Amityville
Horror](/wiki/The_Amityville_Horror_\(1979_film\) "The Amityville Horror
\(1979 film\)")_ further cemented her status as one of Hollywood's leading
ladies. Though it received mixed reviews from critics, _The Amityville Horror_
was a major commercial success, grossing over $86 million in the United
States.[22] [Janet Maslin](/wiki/Janet_Maslin "Janet Maslin") of _[The New
York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ , though giving
the film a mixed review, said Kidder "stubbornly remains the bright-eyed life
of the party [in the film]."[23] In retrospect, Kidder called the film "a
piece of shit."[16] The same year, Kidder hosted an episode of the American
sketch comedy TV show _[Saturday Night Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live
"Saturday Night Live")_.

### 1980–1999: Later
roles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Margot_Kidder&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: 1980–1999: Later roles")]

Kidder continued to work in film throughout the 1980s, appearing in [Paul
Mazursky](/wiki/Paul_Mazursky "Paul Mazursky")'s _[Willie&
Phil](/wiki/Willie_%26_Phil "Willie & Phil")_ and _[Some Kind of
Hero](/wiki/Some_Kind_of_Hero "Some Kind of Hero")_. Her performance in 1981's
_[Heartaches](/wiki/Heartaches_\(film\) "Heartaches \(film\)")_ generated
critical acclaim and Oscar buzz. As court stenographer-cum-private eye Mickey
Raymond, the PG rating that 1983's _[Trenchcoat](/wiki/Trenchcoat_\(film\)
"Trenchcoat \(film\)")_ received led [Disney](/wiki/Disney "Disney") to launch
[Touchstone Pictures](/wiki/Touchstone_Pictures "Touchstone Pictures"). She
appeared opposite [James Garner](/wiki/James_Garner "James Garner") in the
controversial Hollywood crime drama _[The Glitter Dome](/wiki/The_Glitter_Dome
"The Glitter Dome")_ (1984). In 1985, she toplined _[Little
Treasure](/wiki/Little_Treasure "Little Treasure")_ for Columbia Tri-Star with
co-stars [Ted Danson](/wiki/Ted_Danson "Ted Danson") and [Burt
Lancaster](/wiki/Burt_Lancaster "Burt Lancaster"), where she played a
distraught stripper looking for her bank robber-father's buried fortune. In
1986 she was selected as the English narrator for the Japanese animated series
_[The Wonderful Wizard of
Oz](/wiki/The_Wonderful_Wizard_of_Oz_\(1986_TV_series\) "The Wonderful Wizard
of Oz \(1986 TV series\)")_.

A 1982 stage performance of _[Bus Stop](/wiki/Bus_Stop_\(play\) "Bus Stop
\(play\)")_ starring Kidder as Cherie and [Tim Matheson](/wiki/Tim_Matheson
"Tim Matheson") as Bo, was broadcast on [HBO](/wiki/HBO "HBO"). In 1983, she
produced and starred as Eliza Doolittle in a version of
_[Pygmalion](/wiki/Pygmalion_\(1983_film\) "Pygmalion \(1983 film\)")_ with
[Peter O'Toole](/wiki/Peter_O%27Toole "Peter O'Toole") for
[Showtime](/wiki/Showtime_\(TV_network\) "Showtime \(TV network\)").[24] She
produced and starred in the French-Canadian period television film _Louisiana_
(1984) as a plantation owner in the American South who returns from Paris to
find her estate and holdings have been lost.[25] _[Body of
Evidence](/wiki/Body_of_Evidence_\(1988_film\) "Body of Evidence \(1988
film\)")_ (1988), a [CBS](/wiki/CBS "CBS") Movie of the Week, cast Kidder as
nurse who is suspicious that her medical pathologist second husband is a
serial killer. In 1994, Kidder played the bartender at the Broken Skull Tavern
in _[Under a Killing Moon](/wiki/Under_a_Killing_Moon "Under a Killing Moon")_
, an [IBM PC](/wiki/IBM_PC_compatible "IBM PC compatible") adventure game. In
1994 she took time to appear in the [Disney Channel](/wiki/Disney_Channel
"Disney Channel") movie _WindRunner_ , with [Russell
Means](/wiki/Russell_Means "Russell Means") and [Jason
Wiles](/wiki/Jason_Wiles "Jason Wiles"). She made uncredited cameo appearances
in _[Maverick](/wiki/Maverick_\(film\) "Maverick \(film\)")_ (1994) and
_[Delirious](/wiki/Delirious_\(1991_film\) "Delirious \(1991 film\)")_ (1991).
By the mid-1990s, her career began to decline, which was attributed to her
widely publicized [nervous breakdown](/wiki/Nervous_breakdown "Nervous
breakdown") in 1996.[26]

### 2000–2018: Independent films,
television[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Margot_Kidder&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: 2000–2018: Independent films, television")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Margot_Kidder.JPG/170px-
Margot_Kidder.JPG)](/wiki/File:Margot_Kidder.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Margot_Kidder.JPG "Enlarge")

Kidder at Toronto during the Canadian National Exhibition in 2005

In 2000, Kidder played Eileen Canboro in _[Apocalypse III:
Tribulation](/wiki/Apocalypse_III:_Tribulation "Apocalypse III: Tribulation")_
, a [Christian film](/wiki/Christian_film "Christian film") dealing with
[Christian eschatology](/wiki/Christian_eschatology "Christian eschatology")
and the [Rapture](/wiki/Rapture "Rapture"). Kidder stated afterwards that she
did not realize until she was on the set that the movie was serious.[27] Also
that year she appeared in three episodes of Peter Benchley's
_[Amazon](/wiki/Amazon_\(1999_TV_series\) "Amazon \(1999 TV series\)")_ ,
playing a striking role as an insane Canadian woman bent on domination of all
the local tribes. In 2001, she played the [abusive](/wiki/Child_abuse "Child
abuse") mother of a serial killer in "Pique", an episode of _[Law& Order:
Special Victims Unit](/wiki/Law_%26_Order:_Special_Victims_Unit "Law & Order:
Special Victims Unit")_. In 2002, she appeared alongside [Crispin
Glover](/wiki/Crispin_Glover "Crispin Glover") and [Vanessa
Redgrave](/wiki/Vanessa_Redgrave "Vanessa Redgrave") in the film adaptation of
_[Crime and Punishment](/wiki/Crime_and_Punishment_\(2002_Russian_film\)
"Crime and Punishment \(2002 Russian film\)")_.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Kidder appeared off-Broadway in _[The Vagina
Monologues](/wiki/The_Vagina_Monologues "The Vagina Monologues")_ in December
2002,[28] and toured with the show for two years. After this, she appeared on
_[Robson Arms](/wiki/Robson_Arms "Robson Arms")_ , a Canadian
[sitcom](/wiki/Sitcom "Sitcom") set in an apartment block in
[Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver "Vancouver")'s west end. She played a quirky
neighbor of the main cast members. She also had a cameo in _[Rich
Hall](/wiki/Rich_Hall "Rich Hall")'s Election Special_ on [BBC
Four](/wiki/BBC_Four "BBC Four"). In 2006, Kidder played [Jenny
Schecter](/wiki/Jenny_Schecter "Jenny Schecter")'s mother Sandy Ziskin on
_[The L Word](/wiki/The_L_Word "The L Word")_ ; her character was a repressed
Jewish woman coming to terms with her daughter's sexuality.[16] In 2007,
Kidder began appearing on the television series _[Brothers and
Sisters](/wiki/Brothers_%26_Sisters_\(2006_TV_series\) "Brothers & Sisters
\(2006 TV series\)")_ , playing Emily Craft. In 2004, Kidder briefly returned
to the Superman franchise in two episodes of the television series
_[Smallville](/wiki/Smallville_\(TV_series\) "Smallville \(TV series\)")_ , as
[Bridgette Crosby](/wiki/Bridgette_Crosby "Bridgette Crosby"), an emissary of
Dr. Swann (played by her _Superman_ co-star, [Christopher
Reeve](/wiki/Christopher_Reeve "Christopher Reeve")).[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

She portrayed an embattled guidance counselor in the 2008 [gay](/wiki/Gay
"Gay")-themed mystery film _[On the Other Hand,
Death](/wiki/On_the_Other_Hand,_Death "On the Other Hand, Death")_ , as well
as a supporting role as [Laurie Strode](/wiki/Laurie_Strode "Laurie Strode")'s
therapist, in [Rob Zombie](/wiki/Rob_Zombie "Rob Zombie")'s _[Halloween
II](/wiki/Halloween_II_\(2009_film\) "Halloween II \(2009 film\)")_ (2009). In
an interview with the [LGBT](/wiki/LGBT "LGBT") publication _[The
Advocate](/wiki/The_Advocate "The Advocate")_ , Kidder discussed her later
career choices:

“ | I'm not choosy at all! I'll do practically anything. I'm the biggest whore on the block. I live in a little town in Montana, and you have to drag me out of here to get to L.A., so I'm not readily available. But unless it's something sexist or cruel, I just love to work. I've done all sorts of things, but you just haven't seen them because they're often very bad and shown at 4 in the morning.[29] | ”

In 2015 Kidder won an [Emmy](/wiki/Emmy "Emmy") award for [Outstanding
Performer in Children's
Programming](/wiki/Daytime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Performer_in_Children%27s_Programming
"Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Performer in Children's Programming") for
her performance in _[R.L. Stine's The Haunting
Hour](/wiki/R.L._Stine%27s_The_Haunting_Hour "R.L. Stine's The Haunting
Hour")_.[30]

## Personal life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Margot_Kidder&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Personal life")]

Kidder dated former Canadian prime minister [Pierre
Trudeau](/wiki/Pierre_Trudeau "Pierre Trudeau"), directors [Brian De
Palma](/wiki/Brian_De_Palma "Brian De Palma") and [Steven
Spielberg](/wiki/Steven_Spielberg "Steven Spielberg"), writer/director [Tom
Mankiewicz](/wiki/Tom_Mankiewicz "Tom Mankiewicz"), and actor/comedian
[Richard Pryor](/wiki/Richard_Pryor "Richard Pryor").[31] She was married and
divorced three times. Kidder's first husband was American novelist [Thomas
McGuane](/wiki/Thomas_McGuane "Thomas McGuane"), with whom she had her only
child, daughter Maggie McGuane (born 1976). She was married to actor [John
Heard](/wiki/John_Heard_\(actor\) "John Heard \(actor\)") in 1979 for only six
days, and was married to French film director [Philippe de
Broca](/wiki/Philippe_de_Broca "Philippe de Broca") from 1983 to 1984.[32]
After her divorce from De Broca, she said that she preferred the companionship
of her dogs. Kidder had two grandchildren from her daughter Maggie's marriage
to novelist [Walter Kirn](/wiki/Walter_Kirn "Walter Kirn").[33]

She maintained a close friendship with her _Superman_ co-star [Christopher
Reeve](/wiki/Christopher_Reeve "Christopher Reeve"), which lasted from 1978
until his death in 2004. "When you're strapped to someone hanging from the
ceiling for months and months, you get pretty darned close," Kidder told
[CBS](/wiki/CBS "CBS"). "He was such a huge part of my life... He was
complicated, very smart, really smart, and he knew he'd done something
meaningful. He was very aware of that and very happy with that role."[34]
Kidder stated in an interview with _[TV Guide](/wiki/TV_Guide "TV Guide")_
that she was an [atheist](/wiki/Atheist "Atheist").[35]

### Health
problems[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Margot_Kidder&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Health problems")]

In December 1990, Kidder was seriously injured in a car accident which left
her partially paralyzed and confined to a wheelchair. She was unable to work
for two years, causing her financial difficulties. She was diagnosed with
[bipolar disorder](/wiki/Bipolar_disorder "Bipolar disorder"), which was the
cause of a widely publicized [manic episode](/wiki/Mania "Mania") that she
experienced in April 1996. At the time, Kidder had been working on an
[autobiography](/wiki/Autobiography "Autobiography") when her laptop computer
became infected with a [virus](/wiki/Computer_virus "Computer virus"), which
caused it to crash and her to lose three years' worth of drafts.[26] Kidder
flew to [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles") to have the computer
examined by a data retrieval company, who ultimately were unable to retrieve
the files.[26] She entered a manic state and disappeared for four days. She
was found in a backyard by a homeowner and was taken by the [Los Angeles
Police Department](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Police_Department "Los Angeles Police
Department") to [Olive View Medical Center](/wiki/Olive_View_Medical_Center
"Olive View Medical Center") in a distressed state, the caps on her teeth
having been knocked out during a rape attempt.[26] She was later placed in
[psychiatric care](/wiki/Involuntary_commitment "Involuntary commitment").[26]
In 2007, Kidder said that she had not had a manic episode in 11 years, and
credited her well-being to [orthomolecular
medicine](/wiki/Orthomolecular_medicine "Orthomolecular medicine").[36]

### Political
activism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Margot_Kidder&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Political activism")]

Kidder was a longtime supporter of
[Democratic](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party
\(United States\)") and [liberal](/wiki/Liberalism "Liberalism") causes
throughout her career.[37] She credited her interest in politics to
conversations her parents would have over the dinner table during her
childhood; her mother was Canadian with [socialist](/wiki/Socialism
"Socialism") leanings, while her father was originally from the [United
States](/wiki/United_States "United States"), and was a conservative
[Republican](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party
\(United States\)").[38]

She actively supported [Jesse Jackson](/wiki/Jesse_Jackson "Jesse Jackson")'s
bid for the Democratic nomination in the 1984 [U.S. presidential
election](/wiki/U.S._presidential_election,_1984 "U.S. presidential election,
1984"). In the early 1990s, during the first [Gulf War](/wiki/Gulf_War "Gulf
War"), Kidder was branded a "Baghdad Betty" and subjected to abuse for her
remarks questioning the war.[39] In a piece called "Confessions of 'Baghdad
Betty'", styled as a letter to her mother and printed in _[The
Nation](/wiki/The_Nation "The Nation")_ , Kidder responded by explaining and
defending her statements.[40]

As of November 2009, Kidder was the [Montana](/wiki/Montana "Montana") State
Coordinator for [Progressive Democrats of
America](/wiki/Progressive_Democrats_of_America "Progressive Democrats of
America"). The organization's website carried her article "Ax Max", in which
she criticized [Max Baucus](/wiki/Max_Baucus "Max Baucus"), Montana's
[Democratic](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party
\(United States\)") [senator](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States
Senate").[41] On August 23, 2011, Kidder, [Tantoo
Cardinal](/wiki/Tantoo_Cardinal "Tantoo Cardinal"), and dozens of others were
arrested while protesting in [Washington D.C.](/wiki/Washington_D.C.
"Washington D.C.") against the proposed extension of the [Keystone
Pipeline](/wiki/Keystone_Pipeline "Keystone Pipeline").[42] In 2012, she
appeared in a video for _Stop the Frack Attack_ , an environmental
organization working toward regulating [fracking](/wiki/Fracking "Fracking")
practices.[43] When discussing sustainable energy, Kidder said: "The first
thing people have to start facing, contrary to the advertising fed to us by
oil and gas companies, is that environmentalism and economic stability go
hand-in-hand on any long term basis."[38]

On August 22, 2015, Kidder was named the host of a dinner event by the
[Yellowstone County](/wiki/Yellowstone_County "Yellowstone County") Democrats
in [Billings, Montana](/wiki/Billings,_Montana "Billings, Montana") called
"Billings for Bernie" in support of [Bernie Sanders](/wiki/Bernie_Sanders
"Bernie Sanders")' presidential primary bid.[44][45]

She contributed articles to _[CounterPunch](/wiki/CounterPunch
"CounterPunch")_ , a [left-wing](/wiki/Left-wing_politics "Left-wing
politics") magazine, beginning in 2009.[46] In an article expressing her
reaction to the [2016 Democratic National
Convention](/wiki/2016_Democratic_National_Convention "2016 Democratic
National Convention"), she wrote, "I am not an American tonight... I reject
the words I voiced at my citizenship ceremony."[47]

In addition to her campaigning in the United States, Kidder expressed support
for liberal causes in Canada. In 2011, she supported her brother, John Kidder,
in British Columbia, who was running to be a member of Canada's Parliament for
the [Liberal Party](/wiki/Liberal_Party_of_Canada "Liberal Party of Canada"):

“ | I'm here not only because John is a dream candidate but because I'm living in the end game in the United States and it's not funny. Canada is starting the same sort of right-wing, corporate ownership of government, corporate tradeoffs with government, smear campaigns, 'let's lower the corporate tax rate without mentioning it's going to up the private tax rates.' It's happening in Canada. God forbid if anyone should bring up privatizing health care.[48] | ”  
---|---|---  
  
### Citizenship[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Margot_Kidder&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Citizenship")]

Kidder became a [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") citizen
on August 17, 2005, in [Butte, Montana](/wiki/Butte,_Montana "Butte, Montana")
and lived in [Livingston](/wiki/Livingston,_Montana "Livingston,
Montana").[6][49] She said that she decided to become an
[American](/wiki/American_people "American people") citizen to participate in
the voting process, to continue her protests against U.S. [intervention in
Iraq](/wiki/2003_invasion_of_Iraq "2003 invasion of Iraq"), and to be free of
worries about being [deported](/wiki/Deportation "Deportation").[50]

### Death[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Margot_Kidder&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Death")]

Kidder died in her sleep on May 13, 2018, at her home in [Livingston,
Montana](/wiki/Livingston,_Montana "Livingston, Montana"), at the age of
69.[51] The cause of death has not been released.

[DC Comics](/wiki/DC_Comics "DC Comics") stated on their Twitter feed "Thank
you for being the Lois Lane so many of us grew up with. RIP, Margot
Kidder".[52][53]
